review_title: Hilton is the Best Place to Work!
pros: The culture of Hilton is one that makes me proud to work here but to also serve in my community.  Hilton seeks to positively impact the communities in which we work.  This speaks to our commitment to spread the light and warmth of hospitality.  Beyond that, I am encouraged to have a balanced work-life with the flexibility of working from home.  My management team appreciates and rewards hard work.  Hilton believes in taking care of their team members which guarantees that we will take care of our guests. The benefits of "being Hilton" are getting better and better.  The long tenure room discounts gives lifetime discounts for team members with 10 or more years.
cons: As a long time team member, I can say that working for Hilton now is the best it's ever been.  I think a person's work experience depends a lot on the individual and then management.  There will be difficult people and circumstances any where you go but I am grateful that with a dedication to doing my very best and maintaining a positive attitude will get past any challenging experience.

pros: Travel benefits, work from home
cons: They ride you like sea biscuit. Scrutinize your every move. Every call is recorded, analyzed and picked apart. Your sole purpose is to sell, even though they tell you it is service focused. It absolutely has nothing to do with customer service. You yourself are a number, trying to make your numbers. You mean nothing to them, and neither does the guest. The policies they enact are specifically designed to take as much pay from the agent as possible, they do not care how much money you lose because a customer pressed the wrong button, they do not care that you make half as much as you did two years ago because they changed the incentive payout, to benefit them of course. They are thieves, charlatans, who care nothing about their employees or their customers. During the pandemic, we were told not to refund reservations even for countries that had shut down before the US. We were told to delay, delay, delay hoping they would just give up. Hilton is not Hilton anymore, it is owned by an investment company. So it is no longer a “hospitality” company and it shows,

pros: What Hilton has to offer is exactly what they advertise. Competitive benefits, professional, face paced environment, and opportunity for growth.
cons: You have to grow. You can’t just stay where you feel comfortable or master a single position. When they say it’s time for you to get promoted or move you have to. If you decide not to you will almost never be considered again. I can’t speak for the company as a whole on this last one, but my particular property demanded a large amount of your time if you were a manager. I had no work/life balance or friends when I worked for Hilton.

pros: Hilton is a great company to work for when you expect to come in, do your job on time, and have benefits for your free time such as team member rates for hotel rooms across the globe.
cons:
However, franchises and smaller locale hotels often play into the 'family' aspect of business structure. Where this may have benefits for some, this is not for everyone and particularly not for those who wish to stick to their own schedule. Managers often rely on front desk associates to embody the 'multi-tool employee' attitude, no matter what is happening (fire alarms, unruly guests, plumbing). These aspects are not geared at all Hilton branded hotels, but mainly smaller, franchised editions. 
However, the human capital in any workplace can make or break an employees experience.

review_title: Not at all what I had expected from a Hilton Brand
job_title: Customer Service Representative in Shreveport, LA
pros: The only upside to this job was the employee benefits
cons: There was entirely too much favoritism going on at this job. The management was not interested in job performance as much as who LIKED who better, who had the filthiest mouth and everything else that makes people feel included and/or part of something. Not to mention there was always some sort of competition going on for the affection or should I say attention from anyone in a leadership position, (smh) that it was difficult to really understand what was expected of you. Another thing is, I started working for this company a week or so after I buried my mother the year before only to lose the job in March due to Covid-19. Went to apply at Residence inn and it just so happened that the front desk manager who was promoted from housekeeping at this hotel knew the supervisor KG (initials) at the Hilton who apparently spoke against me because Residence inn hired me in a face to face interview and told to come the following day to complete the hiring paperwork. However, during my interview I mentioned working with KG and after I left the interview the front desk manager at Residence inn contacted KG about me, not long after leaving the interview I received a call from Residence inn front desk manager stating they had decided to move on with a different candidate. I don't know what KG said to that front desk manager at Residence inn about me, but whatever it was it cost me job. I had no idea that KG had an issue with me. I learned the operating system Opera fairly quickly and I was at Hilton barely 3 months before Covid-19 showed up, then let go. I was under the impression that I did everything I could to show I'm a hard worker, easy to work with and get along with and everything else. I even earned a gift card as a nice gesture from KG, and she didn't have to do this because I actually did not meet the goal that was set. The gift card was given to me while still in training because I showed initiative once being given the opportunity to start working with the guests. So mixed signals were being delivered and I had no idea. If I sound p**, yes I am because trying to find work in Shreveport is a pain in the a** and it does not have to be that way, but when you are being talked against it makes finding work that much more difficult and the really sad part about all of this is she's not the first person I've run across in Shreveport that has done this to myself and other people who want to do the RIGHT thing whether they're LIKED or DISLIKED for it.

review_title: Kind to the Team Members, but chaotic!
pros: The leadership really does want what's best for the Team Members. They bend over backwards accommodating them. The flexibility is unlike anything I've ever experienced with another employer. They really do promote a culture of inclusion and camaraderie.
cons:
Chaos abounds from the Executives on down. The give direction, so the teams work in that direction. Then, suddenly, out of nowhere, the direction changes...over and over and over. Millions, if not billions, of dollars are wasted in shifting directions and priorities. If you can learn to roll with it, it's a great place to be, but if you like clear direction, it'll drive you mad!

Oh, and the pay is pretty low too.

pros: Hilton knows how to run a hotel. The training you receive overall is great even if you end up at a franchise or another brand. They have a good, whatever it takes culture. Great vacation benefits and they very much encourage you to use your time off and discounts whenever you can.

review_title: When the going gets rough, they throw employees overboard
pros: Decent benefits, good diversity, talk a good game about their culture and values... and about the value of their "team members".

So, when the economy hit a pandemic-sized iceberg, their first reaction was to jettison a large amount of staff who had stuck with the company through pay freezes, pay reductions, furloughs, repeated reorganisations , etc. Staff gave Hilton their loyalty but, despite Hilton's rhetoric, that loyalty was a one-way street.

pros: Flexible Schedule. Paid Holidays. CEO and values of the company. Most of the development coaches are good, but they are overloaded with agent's and can only do so much to help.
cons: Just a few years ago I would have given FIVE stars. I do have hope it will become a great place to work again. There have been too many changes too quickly and not for the better. Almost no support for those of us on the front lines. When we have questions that need to be answered asap because we have an angry guest on the line. We have no one to ask but each other in chat and hope someone responds in a decent amount of time. Their newest reservation system is so slow it's the most inefficient system I've ever worked with. It feels like we are using old dial up service. When concerns are brought up about anything they seem to throw it back at you like your skills might not be good enough. We have a new rating system and it completely changed the way we are evaluated-for the worse. Without warning or a detailed, real explanation. Our incentive bonus system has been completely revamped.-also not in our favor. We were given a small raise instead. Many of us that have been here a long time make a lot less than we did when we started. Hilton has also gotten involved in too many controversial topics at work without really taking into account everyone has a different backgrounds and belief systems. We aren't given enough time for training or even reading our emails. Yet we are expected to keep up with constantly changing policies. When you do take time to train or catch up on emails they score that against your utilization time. This makes no sense if you want seasoned agent's that know how to correctly handle calls.

cons:
Just 1, only 1: the ONE MAJOR PERK that matters, we can't partake in, and that's the EMPLOYEES TRAVEL PROGRAM. At first when I used it in 2017 and 2018, and once in 2020 I was excited. But the REALITY of it, and to be serious here, at our hotel, I can't really speak for everybody else around the world but it in our hotel and as for ME alone, I work too hard, and I don't mind it, this IS part of life and I will just keep working. 

BUT when it's time for me to actually partake of a perk, like a discount or travel program, I expect to have to use it, not for it to be shoved around for those who are "diamond members" OR ANY members , or whatever type of membership they have to have first dibs!!! 

It's not fair for those work hard, and don't take vacations OFTEN and then when they do NEDD TO take A vacation, WE can't find a hotel at a decent price anywhere AND USE OUR PERK, and that's not fair, and I've had enough!!!!

So I might as well just work at ANY hotel, REGARDLESS OF THE CHAIN, it doesn't matter!!

I might as well work for alliance residential, or GreyStar communities, a job is a job , they see us this way anyway when we complain about something, "you don't like it there's the door another person would go ahead and take your place"!! 

Well that's fine, there's plenty of hotels out there, plenty of apartment complexes out there to work at, I can see at the same way. Why the hell bother giving us 30 employee hotel stays for if I CANT EVEN GET 4 TO 5 NIGHTS BOOKED 1 YEAR IN ADVANCE. THAT WAS THE ONLY REASON I'M STILL HERE. 

30 HOTEL STAYS, get out of here with that!!!!@
